Hello:
Here are some resources about snow removal from the Knowledge Network that might help you.
•   This is a document from Fishers, Indiana, where they reorganized and consolidated snow removal processes in order to save money, improve services and make more efficient use of limited resources: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302058/What_Works_Snow_Removal_Fishers_IN
•   This example deals with snow removal in Salt Lake City. The document is about how they use specific design criteria when reviewing a project or development within the corporate limits of Salt Lake City: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302088/Design_Criteria_for_Snow_Removal
•   This article highlights six snow removal innovations from cities across the country. It includes using different types of treatments, street improvements, geographic information systems, and safe sledding programs: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/303403/Olathe_Snow_Removal_Programhttp://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2860/Snow_Removal_Innovations
•   And this is a similar question that was asked on the Knowledge Network. Perhaps the answers posted here will help you with your research:  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/20905
Peggy Chasler
Knowledge Network Intern
pchasler@icma.org

author: John Miller
text:
The Village of Taos Ski Valley, located in northern New Mexico elev. 9400', is looking to increase its snow removal services throughout the Village area, yet due to its small size and tax base we are having difficulty finding options to finance this project.  
With snow removal being such an integral part of an alpine village, we want to increase this service in order to increase the quality of life that should be availible to our residents.  Currently, our snow removal services are adaquate for what is required, but with increaseing development and the need to promote continuity throughout our village we are looking to beging to take over snow removal service in many new open pedestrian walkways and plazas.  
This increase in snow removal responsibility, coupled with the decreasing snow storage areas from new development has put VTSV in a compromising position in regards to liability, legal and financial.  
Because we only maintain a full time yearly population of less than 100 residents, our property tax revenue is very small in comparison to other mountain ski towns.  With this in mind, we are searching for ideas to increase funding for this increased service.  
If any small towns or villages could help us understand what would be an appropriate revenue source for this project, possibly in the form of a tax assessment or district, an enterprise fund, lodgers tax, or anything that another municipality is currently using sucessfully, it would be greatly appreciated. 
John Anthony Miller III
Intern -  Village of Tao Ski Valley, New Mexico

title: Snow Removal funding options for small alpine village
